column1: well it's not like i was watching many cartoons anyway.
a.) i don't like the writing in naruto. i couldn't get past a few episodes before i gave up on that show.
b.) i'm currently in the midst of a bit of writer's block. i've been wanting to make a comic since forever
column2: but i want to have at least a decent idea of how the whole story unfolds from beginning to end
column3: since i don't want this to be one of those "pull stuff out of my ass as i go and things begin to make less sense as time goes on" things (cough inuyasha cough). got stuck right after issue 3.

column1: the whole comic starts with the main character not knowing his own identity
column2: trying to find it and giving up
column3: then several years later accidentally awakens a new power which rekindles his search. issue 2 introduces a mysterious organization of antagonists
column4: and issue 3 fleshes it out just a bit by giving them a name (the greywolves) and ends with them learning of gier's whereabouts and hunting him down (for

column1: post this point i was having a hard time moving the story forward
column2: mostly on account of having no actual idea where gier should even begin to look for clues about his past.

column1: so fast forward to me being bored out of my skull and watching a compilation of fight scenes from naruto. as one character is facing off against an entire clan
column2: i kinda realized something that's almost cliche for that genre - a group setting up an ambush for someone. it's cliche but i could move the story forward with something like that - if
column4: a bit of information is "conveniently" conveyed to gier which lures him away from bastion city to a smaller town (to reduce the chance of unwanted attention - bastion city's pretty densely populated). and there
column6: they attack him. haven't quite figured out where that goes or how i should use it to drive the plot
column7: but it should be a pretty good start.

column1: you know what else is a cliche? starting a story with a character with no memory of their past while their first question is "who am i?". it's basically starting a blank slate with no history. i've heard of two games that use this; one's dust
column2: the other is some blonde girl that controls gravity (forgot the name of that other game). but this is the fifth time i hear someone suggesting they write their character like this in the beginning.

column1: @killamaaki how about the organisation attack his house? basically the protagonist is a threat to them because he knows something  that he himself doesn't know
column2: so they wanna find and kill him as soon as they can.
but didn't end up applying

column1: one thing is it's now about what he knows
column2: it's more what he's capable of. and taking him on in the city isn't as desirable as luring him away - each time they've fought
column3: they attracted the attention of police in the city. so luring him somewhere more remote and secluded would make things a lot easier for them. also he basically lives in an apartment
column4: so attacking him there attracts even more attention (can you imagine the noise complaints for a couple of characters with special powers going all out? lol)

column1: there was this one moment where i was staring at the spinning wheel in the lower right corner of unity which shows you that it's compiling code
column2: and i was thinking to myself "oh my god this is taking forever
column3: why is it taking so long? it doesn't usually take this long!". cue a little bit later
column4: i realized it was just me and it compiled just as quickly as it normally does lol.
